message: I'm not sure about the "solving a problem" bit, but I've always used Preconditions as a way of simply giving a story more "flavor"  It's always one of the easiest appreciations to include
What does this mean: "...only the preconditions can actually solve the problem"?
>What does this mean: "...only the preconditions can actually solve the problem"?
And then they walk into a bar with a priest and a rabbi...  Oh wait, that wasn't a setup for a joke?  :-}
Got it.

Here is the definition of Preconditions: Preconditions (Overall Storyline) -- [Type] --
unessential restrictions imposed on the effort to
reach the goal -- When meeting the requirement
is made contingent upon some nonessential
restriction, the extra baggage is
referred to as Pre-conditions. Depending upon
the nature of the Pre-conditions and the nature
of a character, it may turn out that although the
pre-requisites will achieve the goal, the goal
itself is improper and only the Pre-conditions
can actually solve the problem. Misplaced
emphasis is a common thematic exploration.
I think its supposed to be simultaneously
Yet, I cannot seem to sneak one into "Cargo". And the ones that are there naturally are just a bit lame -- they are such low-hanging fruit that they don't color anything.
that sounds good
haha.
Although, at its strictest, it's supposed to be something that has to be done before the Requirements can be met.

A priest has to go across the desert to find a princess. A sultan shows up and says, "Take my daughter with you, so she can find a priest." The two travel together and fall in love... the precondition of "taking the daughter" has solved the problem of "no love"
Booyaa
lol
I think it's actually "The Sure Thing" written by Sheherezade
I usually just make it a task the Protagonist has to do that has nothing to do with the actual Goal itself
@SandyStone which would be *why* they are imposing restrictions.
nice
yes you're right - i was thinking prerequisites and preconditions
My interpretation is the sometimes the person "imposing restrictions" may actually be more on the right track than the Protagonist is ... sometimes.
Perhaps ... it may be knowing or unknowing.
